item.title: In "just did a bad thing" you said at the end of the song "just did a strange thing, now everything's pink". You also commonly say your songs are based on how it felt to write them. how did everything become pink during the songwriting (whether literally or metaphorically)? Also big fan of your vids, bill
item.description:
1.29.26 3:35 am
Q: In "just did a bad thing" you said at the end of the song "just did a strange thing, now everything's pink". You also commonly say your songs are based on how it felt to write them. how did everything become pink during the songwriting (whether literally or metaphorically)? Also big fan of your vids, bill
A: i'll tell you exactly what that is. it's a song ending. it's a very strange thing for a song to end. when you're in the song, the song is the whole world. but eventually the song has to end and you have to transition into the world outside of that song. so song endings, at least for me, often have this weird shocking quality to them, kind of like a vestubule of a building, or a decompression chamber. or that space between the inner and outer wrapper, on a loaf of bread. nevermind, better metaphor, it's like the song is dying. the song ends, so the ending of songs often sounds like the song is being killed. that way a plausible next move for the song at that point would be to no longer be playing

item.title: disclaimer: this might come off as more of an existential rant than a question. i love how into songwriting you are. you are among the only people on earth that i really resonate with when they talk about it. but then again, one thing differentiates us two. you actually do it. you put out songs. i understand everything you're talking about when answering these questions, i feel as if i percieve it the same way you do, sometimes i even console myself saying it's what i live for, yet i still don't make music. you give beautiful inspiring insights, yet i still can't regularly put them to use. it means so much to me that it scares me out of it. and it's this constant cycle of wanting it too much and not wanting it enough. sometimes i catch myself in the middle ground with the guitar in my hand but that middle ground is so unpredictable and it throws me off every time it comes by me. it's so short as well. it leaves me dazed, journaling for so long in attempt to uncover what made me land at the sweet spot. i almost always get too self conscious before anything worth sharing feels complete, yet it always gives me a little hope. but it's been 6 years... i've been officially in love with music for the last 6 years. 4 of which i have been in this stagnant state. i convince myself i dont need it. i judge myself when i see others succeed. how do i actually get myself to actually and consistently do it??? how do i balance out wanting it too little and too much on a regular basis??? i love creating so much it genuinely, literally hurts when i'm not doing it. and most of the time i'm not doing it. i'm sorry if this is a bit intense, i don't mean to burden you with any emotions. but if you have any wisdom to share with me, it would be greatly appreciated. thank you for everything you do by the way
item.description:
1.29.26 5:40 pm
Q: disclaimer: this might come off as more of an existential rant than a question. i love how into songwriting you are. you are among the only people on earth that i really resonate with when they talk about it. but then again, one thing differentiates us two. you actually do it. you put out songs. i understand everything you're talking about when answering these questions, i feel as if i percieve it the same way you do, sometimes i even console myself saying it's what i live for, yet i still don't make music. you give beautiful inspiring insights, yet i still can't regularly put them to use. it means so much to me that it scares me out of it. and it's this constant cycle of wanting it too much and not wanting it enough. sometimes i catch myself in the middle ground with the guitar in my hand but that middle ground is so unpredictable and it throws me off every time it comes by me. it's so short as well. it leaves me dazed, journaling for so long in attempt to uncover what made me land at the sweet spot. i almost always get too self conscious before anything worth sharing feels complete, yet it always gives me a little hope. but it's been 6 years... i've been officially in love with music for the last 6 years. 4 of which i have been in this stagnant state. i convince myself i dont need it. i judge myself when i see others succeed. how do i actually get myself to actually and consistently do it??? how do i balance out wanting it too little and too much on a regular basis??? i love creating so much it genuinely, literally hurts when i'm not doing it. and most of the time i'm not doing it. i'm sorry if this is a bit intense, i don't mean to burden you with any emotions. but if you have any wisdom to share with me, it would be greatly appreciated. thank you for everything you do by the way
A: all i can say is, one day you will probably find yourself on the other side of this conversation, advising someone who is envious of the things you seemingly so simply just "can do". but of course they'll have no idea what it took you to get there

item.title: do you remember the way some songs were written when they become relevant to a specific moment in your life? eg. "just did a bad thing", and coping with the fact that you just did a bad thing by remembering your written wisdom on the subject of doing a bad thing
item.description:
1.29.26 8:56 pm
Q: do you remember the way some songs were written when they become relevant to a specific moment in your life? eg. "just did a bad thing", and coping with the fact that you just did a bad thing by remembering your written wisdom on the subject of doing a bad thing
A: actually what happened on that one was i had narrowed it down to about 20 choices for which song (or song idea) was going to be the next one to finish and record, and that was one of them. it was certainly not my favorite, but it must not have been my least favorite because it made the top 20. that idea itself is not related to any particular bad thing or other, it's just a song idea which i apparently thought was cool when i came up with it. and slightly cool when i picked it for the top 20. Then i started narrowing it down by eliminating ones from the 20, that was probably one of the first to get eliminated, then i kept eliminating them and eventually i got it down to 1, but i didnt really want to do that one either, so i eliminated that one as well. I just sort of frustratedly shrugged and said "well that wasn't the point", and i un-eliminated all of them and then just quickly chose the "bad thing" one, because it was kind of the one that felt the weakest. because the point is that it shouldn't matter which song you choose, any idea can be made good. And the truth is, it can actually be very energizing to work with a weaker idea, because it makes the creative engine turn on stronger, to compensate. and that's certainly what i noticed, after getting started on it and writing the next 8 bars or so. so sometimes i refer to the "bad thing" as the fact that i accidentally eliminated all of my choices and ended up going with the weakest one. Other times, i tell the story that the "bad thing" was that i spent simultaneously too much and too little time on the production of the song, and accidentally spent the exact right amount of time, but that's another story

item.title: i love art and music more than anything but I am so hung up on the fact that I suck at everything and am too timid to step out of my comfort zone that I pretty much float through life not expressing myself or having any meaningful experiences at all. i know that life has the power to be so beautiful but I let all of my mental issues hold me back. how do you keep yourself from living in your head and letting anxiety and perfectionism feed inaction (if that's something you've experienced before)?

item.title: i used to be so incredibly in love with the art i saw online. it brought me so much joy and happiness to see that it could evoke so much emotion and was one of my biggest motivations to create my own things. but about a year ago, i saw a piece of art that absolutely broke me in the best and worst way possible. it resonated so deeply with me and made me sob 'till my eyes hurt because of how unbearable the feelings i had for it was. and unexpectedly, all that inspiration and joy that art had sparked within me had been so heavy on my mind that it turned into jealousy and envy. i was jealous because i loved it so much that it hurt to know and realize that i can't make something like it, that i just never put in the effort to be like that. i can't fully enjoy the artists i love anymore, because i feel so guilty and shameful for basically hating them for having the will and passion that i lack. i at least kept all that envy to myself and never spoke of it, but i've been hurting deeply inside for so long and everytime i try to make something now i just feel so stupid for even trying. it feels like these hateful thoughts have been eating away at me forever. i don't want that. i really don't want to hate. i don't want to be a hateful person at all. i just want to love. to love everything around me, and myself and what i do. how do i love again?
item.description:
2.2.26 12:13 am
Q: i used to be so incredibly in love with the art i saw online. it brought me so much joy and happiness to see that it could evoke so much emotion and was one of my biggest motivations to create my own things. but about a year ago, i saw a piece of art that absolutely broke me in the best and worst way possible. it resonated so deeply with me and made me sob 'till my eyes hurt because of how unbearable the feelings i had for it was. and unexpectedly, all that inspiration and joy that art had sparked within me had been so heavy on my mind that it turned into jealousy and envy. i was jealous because i loved it so much that it hurt to know and realize that i can't make something like it, that i just never put in the effort to be like that. i can't fully enjoy the artists i love anymore, because i feel so guilty and shameful for basically hating them for having the will and passion that i lack. i at least kept all that envy to myself and never spoke of it, but i've been hurting deeply inside for so long and everytime i try to make something now i just feel so stupid for even trying. it feels like these hateful thoughts have been eating away at me forever. i don't want that. i really don't want to hate. i don't want to be a hateful person at all. i just want to love. to love everything around me, and myself and what i do. how do i love again?
A: i dont think i see anything wrong here, you're just finding out how sensitive and intense this game is. your feelings of envy also indicate to me, i think, that you know you're meant to be involved in it somehow. and then also, it's important to remember that this hypnotic superpower you've seen on display is not something that's held under a lock and key somewhere. it flows through all of us, in different ways all the time. actually, what you experienced from that time you saw that thing, that probably says more about you than it does about them. it's at least a 50/50 collaborative moment you had between you and the artist. Perhaps just the other day, that artist maybe saw something by another artist that made them melt with envy. maybe something that would not have moved you in the same way. but then let's say that other artist (the second artist, you being the third, for those keeping score) maybe sees a piece of your work, something youve done, and maybe THAT moves them to tears and sends them into a jealous rage. it all comes full circle, but the knock out 'wow' factor is something that visits us all, it just doesnt like to be told exactly when and where

item.title: are diminished 7 chords even real
item.description:
2.3.26 1:53 pm
Q: are diminished 7 chords even real
A: i think what can happen is, the naming system taught in your textbooks will naturally lead you to a bias that certain namable chords within that system are more common than the ones which dont have names, which is not quite true. BUT, they still very much exist in actual music. at least that one does. (hint: in the key of C, the ones youre most likely to see are the ones like C#dim7, F#dim7, or G#min7. and the next chord will probably be a halfstep higher, such as Dmin7, C/G (C over G bass), or Amin)
